review.title: A Description Logic Primer
review.abstract: This paper provides a self-contained first introduction to description logics (DLs). The main concepts and features are explained with examples before syntax and semantics of the DL SROIQ are defined in detail. Additional sections review light-weight DL languages, discuss the relationship to the Web Ontology Language OWL and give pointers to further reading.

As its name suggests, DLs were used in knowledge transmission long before the advent of ontological modeling, and as such are equipped with formal semantics dating back to the first DL modeling of languages in the mid-1980s.

sections.heading: 1. Basic Building Blocks of DL Ontologies
sections.text: Description logics (DLs) provide tools for modeling relationships between entities in an area of interest. In DLs, there are three types of entities: concepts, roles, and individual names.1 Concepts denote groups of individuals, roles denote binary relationships between individuals, and individual names denote individual individuals in this area. Readers familiar with first-order logic will recognize these as non-ary predicates, binary predicates, and constants. An ontology that models, for example, the domain of people and their family relationships could use concepts such as parent to denote the set of all parents and women to denote the totality of all female individuals, roles such as parentOf to dense the (binary) relationship between parents and their children, and individual names such as Julia and john to denote the individuals Julia and John.Unlike a database, a DL ontology does not fully describe a particular situation or the "state of the world"; rather, it consists of a series of assertions that must be described in three axioms.

sections.heading: 1.1. Asserting Facts with ABox Axioms
sections.text: The most common ABox axioms are concept assertions such as Mother (julia), (1) which claim that Julia is mother or, more specifically, that the individual named julia is an instance of the concept of mother. Role assertions describe relationships between named individuals. In OWL, concepts and roles are respectively known as classes and properties; see Section 6.The previous sentence shows that it can be quite awkward to point out explicitly that the relationships expressed by an axiom are relationships between individuals, settings and relationships, each known as classes and properties.

Furthermore, such additional concept expressions can be combined with equivalence and inclusion to describe more complex situations such as the disagreement of concepts in which it is claimed that two concepts do not share instances.

sections.heading: 1.3. Modelling Relationships between Roles with RBox Axioms
sections.text: In terms of concepts, DLs support role inclusion and the equivalence axioms of roles. For example, ancestorOf (7) states that ElternOf is a subrole of ancestorOf, i.e. that any pair of individuals who are related by ElternOf is also related by ancestorOf. Consequently, (2) and (7) together imply that Julia is an ancestor of John.In role inclusion axioms, the role composition can be used to describe roles such as uncleOf. If Charles is a brother of Julia and Julia is a parent of John, then Charles is an uncle of John.This type of relationship between the roles BrotherOf, parentOf and uncleOf is captured by the complex role inclusion, inclusion axiom brotherOf its parent UncleOf. sections.heading: 2. Constructors for Concepts and Roles
sections.text: To describe more complex situations, DLs allow new concepts and roles to be constructed using a variety of different constructors. We distinguish concept and role constructors depending on whether concept or role expressions are constructed. In the case of concepts, further basic Boolean constructors, role constraints, and nominal / enumeration can be separated. At the end of this section, we return to the additional types of RBox axioms omitted in Section 1.3.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nominals
sections.text: In addition to defining concepts related to other concepts (and roles), it can also be useful to define a concept by simply enumerating its instances. For example, we could define the concept of Beatle by enumerating its instances: john, paul, george, and ringo. Enumerations are not natively supported in DLs, but they can be simulated in DLs using denominations. A nominal term is a concept that has exactly one instance. (22) It is interesting to note that the enumeration in our example could be expressed by using denominations associated with being a Beatle (john).

sections.heading: 7. Further Reading
sections.text: This paper can only be an initial introduction to Description Logic and OWL. Further details, especially with respect to formal semantics and modeling, can be found in the extensive lecture notes for the Foundations of Description Logics course given at the Reasoning Web Summer School 2011 [11]. For more detailed coverage of OWL and its relationship to DL, we recommend the textbook Foundations of Semantic Web Technologies [7]. This introductory text also covers the relationship of DLs to First Order Logic, DL Query Answering and extensions for rule-based modelling (with respect to keys in OWL), which we have omitted here. A more in-depth discussion of Description Logic and related research topics is provided by the Description Logic Handbook, which also covers interesting aspects of deduction algorithms and the imperative complexity that go beyond the scope of this paper.
